description: From Middle English surveyen, from Old French sourveoir, surveer (“to oversee”), from sour-, sur- (“over”) + veoir, veeir (“to see”), from Latin videre. See sur- and vision.

entries.meaning: The act of surveying; a general view.
examples: Under his proud survey the city lies.

entries.meaning: A particular view; an examination, especially an official examination, of a particular group of items, in order to ascertain the condition, quantity, or quality.
examples: A survey of the stores of a ship; a survey of roads and bridges; a survey of buildings.

entries.meaning: The operation of finding the contour, dimensions, position, or other particulars of any part of the Earth's surface.
A measured plan and description of any portion of country.
examples: The owners of the adjoining plots had conflicting surveys.

entries.meaning: An examination of the opinions of a group of people.
examples: The local council conducted a survey of its residents to help it decide whether to go ahead with the roadside waste collection service.

entries.meaning: A questionnaire or similar instrument used for examining the opinions of a group of people.
examples: I just filled out that survey on roadside waste pick-up.

entries.meaning: (historical) An auction at which a farm is let for a lease for lives.
(US) A district for the collection of customs under a particular officer.

verbs.description: survey (third-person singular simple present surveys, present participle surveying, simple past and past participle surveyed)

entries.meaning: To inspect, or take a view of; to view with attention, as from a high place; to overlook
examples: He stood on a hill, and surveyed the surrounding country.

entries.meaning: To view with a scrutinizing eye; to examine.
To examine with reference to condition, situation, value, etc.; to examine and ascertain the state of
examples: It was his job to survey buildings in order to determine their value and risks.

entries.meaning: To determine the form, extent, position, etc., of, as a tract of land, a coast, harbor, or the like, by means of linear and angular measurements, and the application of the principles of geometry and trigonometry
examples: to survey land or a coast

entries.meaning: To examine and ascertain, as the boundaries and royalties of a manor, the tenure of the tenants, and the rent and value of the same.
examples: all the Tenants Leases and Copies are surveyed

entries.meaning: To investigate the opinions, experiences, etc., of people by asking them questions; to conduct a survey; to administer a questionnaire.
